case_name: Commissioner of War Profits Tax v. Binod Mills Co. Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 228 to 230 of 1960 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeals Nos. 228 to 230 of 1960. Appeals from the judgment and decree dated February 4, 1957, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court  Indore Bench  at Indore in Civil Reference No.15 of 1952.

facts.text: Appeals from judgment and decree dated February 4, 1957 of Madhya Pradesh High Court Indore Bench in Civil Reference No.15 of 1952.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals from the judgment and decree dated February 4, 1957, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court  Indore Bench  at Indore in Civil Reference No.15 of 1952. Se? ?,, B. K. B. Yaidu and 1. N. Shroff, for the appellants.

facts.text: Judgment of the Supreme Court delivered on April 3, 1962 by AYYANGAR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1962. April 3. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by. AYYANGAR, J.-Rule 4  1  b  of Sch. 1 headed   Rules for the companyputation of profits for the purposes of War Profits Tax of the Gwalior War Profits Tax Ordinance,

facts.text: Respondent Binod Mills Co. Ltd. carried on business at Ujjain in the State of Gwalior.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent-Binod Mills Co. Ltd. which had its business at Ujjain in the State of Gwalior was a companypany whose profits were liable to War Profits Tax under the Ordinance.

facts.text: Binod Mills Co. Ltd. was managed by managing agency firm M/s. Binodiram Balchand.

anchor.surface_text: The companypany was managed by a managing agency firm-M s. Binodiram Balchand which had, by reason of its shareholding exceeding 50 of the issued sharecapital, a companytrolling interest in the companypany.

facts.text: M/s. Binodiram Balchand had shareholding exceeding 50% of issued share capital, having controlling interest in Binod Mills Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: which had, by reason of its shareholding exceeding 50 of the issued sharecapital, a companytrolling interest in the companypany. The respondent-company was assessed to War Profits Tax for three chargeable accounting, periods-July 1, 1944, to December 31, 1944 , January 1, 1945, to December 31, 1945, and January 1, 1946, to June 30, 1946.

facts.text: Binod Mills Co. Ltd. assessed to War Profits Tax for period July 1, 1944 to December 31, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent-company was assessed to War Profits Tax for three chargeable accounting, periods-July 1, 1944, to December 31, 1944 , January 1, 1945, to December 31, 1945, and January 1, 1946, to June 30, 1946. During each of these accounting-periods the respondent-company had paid remuneration to its managing- agents

facts.text: Binod Mills Co. Ltd. assessed to War Profits Tax for period January 1, 1945 to December 31, 1945.

anchor.surface_text: January 1, 1945, to December 31, 1945, and January 1, 1946, to June 30, 1946. During each of these accounting-periods the respondent-company had paid remuneration to its managing- agents and claimed to deduct the remuneration so paid in the companyputation of its business profits during these three periods.

facts.text: Binod Mills Co. Ltd. assessed to War Profits Tax for period January 1, 1946 to June 30, 1946.

anchor.surface_text: and January 1, 1946, to June 30, 1946. During each of these accounting-periods the respondent-company had paid remuneration to its managing- agents and claimed to deduct the remuneration so paid in the companyputation of its business profits during these three periods. The assessingofficer disallowed the claim

facts.text: During each accounting period, Binod Mills paid remuneration to managing agents and claimed deduction in computation of business profits.

anchor.surface_text: During each of these accounting-periods the respondent-company had paid remuneration to its managing- agents and claimed to deduct the remuneration so paid in the companyputation of its business profits during these three periods. The assessingofficer disallowed the claim on the ground that the remuneration received by the managing-agency firm had number been factually assessed

facts.text: Assessing officer disallowed deduction claim because remuneration not factually assessed in hands of managing agent.

anchor.surface_text: The assessingofficer disallowed the claim on the ground that the remuneration received by the managing-agency firm had number been factually assessed in the hands of the managing-agent and that companysequently the matter was companyered by the opening words of r. 4 and number saved by proviso  b  to the rule.

facts.text: Appeal against assessment order dismissed by appellate authority.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal against this order of assessment was dismissed by the appellate authority and thereafter by the Commissioner of War Profits Tax in revision. But at the request of the respondent the Commissioner submitted a reference under s. 46  1  of the Ordinance to the High Court

facts.text: Revision by Commissioner of War Profits Tax dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: and thereafter by the Commissioner of War Profits Tax in revision. But at the request of the respondent the Commissioner submitted a reference under s. 46  1  of the Ordinance to the High Court of Madhya Pradesh of the following question for its decision

facts.text: Commissioner submitted reference under s.46(1) to Madhya Pradesh High Court at request of respondent.

anchor.surface_text: But at the request of the respondent the Commissioner submitted a reference under s. 46  1  of the Ordinance to the High Court of Madhya Pradesh of the following question for its decision Whether in companyputing the profits of a business carried on by a companypany deduction shall be made in respect of any remuneration to any managing-agent

facts.text: Consolidated reference in respect of three chargeable accounting periods to High Court.

anchor.surface_text: There was a companysolidated reference in respect of the three chargeable accounting periods. The learned Judges of the High Court answered the question in favour of the respondent and held that the remuneration, even though paid to a managingagent who had a companytrolling interest in the companypany,

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh High Court answered reference question in favour of respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges of the High Court answered the question in favour of the respondent and held that the remuneration, even though paid to a managingagent who had a companytrolling interest in the companypany, was a permissible deduction for the purpose of companyputing the profits of the companypany for the purposes of the War Profits Tax.

facts.text: Appellant moved High Court for certificates under s.47 of Ordinance, which were granted.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was thereafter moved by the appellant for the grant of certificates of fitness for appeals to this Court under s. 47 of the Ordinance and the certificates having been granted these three appeals, which relate to the three chargeable accounting periods have been preferred to this Court.

facts.text: No dispute that M/s. Binodiram Balchand were directors of the company within meaning of Ordinance and had controlling interest.

Rule 4  1  b  of Sch. 1 headed   Rules for the companyputation of profits for the purposes of War Profits Tax of the Gwalior War Profits Tax Ordinance, Samvat 2001  hereinafter referred to as the Ordinance , provided In companyputing the profits of a business carried on by a companypany, no deduction shall be made in respect of-  1  remuneration paid to directors if during any part of the accounting period companycerned they had companytrolling interest in the companypany Provided that this sub-rule shall number apply--  a   b  to the remuneration of any managing agent where such remuneration is included in the profits of The managing agents business for the purposes of the War Profits Tax.

concepts.interpretation: Prohibits deduction of remuneration paid to directors with controlling interest unless the remuneration to managing agent is included in the managing agent's profits for War Profits Tax; 'is included' interpreted as liable to inclusion under the Ordinance as part of chargeable profits, irrespective of actual inclusion in return or assessment order.

anchor.surface_text: Section 4  1  of the Ordinance is the charging section and it enacts 4.  1  Subject to the provisions of this Ordinance, there shall, in respect of any business to which this Ordinance applies, be charged, levied and paid on the amount by which the profits during any chargeable period exceed the standard profits, an excess profit tax  in this Ordinance referred to as the War Profits Tax  which shall be equal to 60 per cent. of the aforesaid amount.

concepts.interpretation: Charging section levying War Profits Tax at 60% on excess profits over standard profits.

arguments.claim: 'Included' refers to actual inclusion by assessing officer in the assessment of the managing agent.

arguments.court_reasoning: High Court held equivalent to 'liable to be included'; Supreme Court agreed not to pursue.

arguments.claim: Proviso (b) gives option to controlling director/managing agent to include remuneration in own return (taxed personally) or in company's (taxed there); failure to include in own return opts for company taxation.

arguments.court_reasoning: Theory breaks as no reverse exemption for agent; no statutory option; leads to absurd policy results burdening minority shareholders; anomalies if assessor disagrees.

arguments.claim: Proviso cannot vest absolute discretion in assessing authority; 'is included' means 'is liable to be included'.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges repelled this submission by holding that the proviso companyld number be companystrued as to vest in the assessing authority an absolute discretion to assess either the companypany or the managing-agent. They read the words ,is included as equivalent to is liable to be included

arguments.claim: 'Is included' means inclusion under the terms of the Ordinance as chargeable (liable to be included), regardless of actual return or assessment.

anchor.surface_text: This leaves for companysideration the meaning that is included refers to the inclusion under the provisions of the Ordinance. If this meaning were accepted it would number matter whether the managing agent has or has number included the sum in his return or whether the assessing authorities have or have number done their duty by having the remuneration included- in the taxable profits of the managingagent.

arguments.claim: Rule 4(1)(b) not designed to avoid double taxation by option, as no reverse exemption for managing agent if taxed in company.

anchor.surface_text: The theory propounded regarding the provision being one for avoidance of double taxation in the manner above indicated by vesting a discretion in the companytrolling-Director breaks even on a cursory examination. Let us assume that the managingagent opts to have the companypany taxed and submits a return on behalf of the companypany in which numberdeduction is claimed in respect of this item and an assessment is made accepting that return.

arguments.claim: Interpreting as agent's return inclusion leads to unreasonable result: agent always chooses company taxation to shift burden to other shareholders.

anchor.surface_text: Obviously it would always be in the interest of the managing-agent to have the tax paid by the companypany if by that means, as is suggested by Mr. Sen, he companyld obtain absolution from the obligation of paying the tax himself, for if the tax is paid by the companypany the loss involved in the payment of the tax would fall on him only to the extent of his shareholding,

arguments.claim: Proviso inapplicable only where remuneration not liable to tax under Ordinance, e.g., s.5(1)(b) charitable exemption.

anchor.surface_text: Where the remuneration of the managingagent was number under the Ordinance liable to be brought to tax the position would be different and that is just what is indicated as that which would render the proviso inapplicable. holdings.text: We therefore consider that the learned Judges of the High Court answered the question referred to them correctly.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court rejects interpretations requiring actual inclusion in return or assessment as leading to discretion, absurdity, and unfairness to shareholders; holds 'is included' means liable under Ordinance, allowing deduction.

holdings.text: the meaning that is included refers to the inclusion under the provisions of the Ordinance.

anchor.surface_text: This leaves for consideration the meaning that is included refers to the inclusion under the provisions of the Ordinance. If this meaning were accepted it would not matter whether the managing agent has or has not included the sum in his return or whether the assessing authorities have or have not done their duty by having the remuneration included- in the taxable profits of the managingagent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dismisses alternatives (inclusion in return or by AO) due to anomalies, lack of reverse exemption, and policy issues; accepts statutory chargeability interpretation as harmonious and reasonable.

holdings.text: r. 4 (1) (b) is not a rule designed for the avoidance of double taxation in the sense in which learned Counsel for the appellant suggests that it is.

anchor.surface_text: Obviously therefore r. 4 1  b  is not a rule designed for the avoidance of double taxation in the sense in which learned Counsel for the appellant suggests that it is.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No reverse exemption for agent if denied to company; independent assessment units under Ordinance; option theory fails as agent remains taxable.

holdings.text: We consider that the construction suggested by Mr. Sen which leads to such an unreasonable result and inflicts an unjust injury on the other shareholders is not any proper interpretation of the provision.

anchor.surface_text: We consider that the construction suggested by Mr. Sen which leads to such an unreasonable result and inflicts an unjust injury on the other shareholders is not any proper interpretation of the provision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Inclusion in agent's return allows shifting tax burden to minority shareholders via control, contrary to reasonable construction.

holdings.text: Except in case where the remuneration received by a managing agent is not liable to tax under the Ordinance, it is the managing-agent that would be liable to pay tax on his remuneration and notwithstanding that the company is a controlled company the remuneration paid by it to the managing agent would be a permissible deduction by reason of the exception to the opening words of r. 4 (1) contained in proviso (b).

anchor.surface_text: Except in case where the remuneration received by a managing agent is number liable to tax under the Ordinance, it is the managing-agent that would be liable to pay tax on his remuneration and notwithstanding that the company is a controlled company the remuneration paid by it to the managing agent would be a permissible deduction by reason of the exception to the opening words of r. 4 1 contained in proviso  b .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Proviso saves deduction unless remuneration exempt (e.g., s.5(1)(b)); otherwise, liable in agent's hands allows company deduction.

holdings.text: since in the case before us it is admitted that the remuneration received by the managing-agent was liable to be included in the computation of his profits for the purposes of the War Profits Tax and therefore neither the fact that the managing-agent did not include the sum in his return, nor the default of the assessing authority to correct this error by including the sum in his assessment, is any reason for depriving the respondent company of the benefit of proviso (b) to r. 4 (1).

anchor.surface_text: since in the case before us it is admitted that the remuneration received by the managing-agent was liable to be include in the computation of his profits for the purposes of the War Profits Tax and therefore neither the fact that the managing-agent did number include the sum in his return,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies interpretation to facts: remuneration liable, no actual inclusion needed; deduction allowed despite defaults.
